formal_accuser.name: Jean Colin
formal_accuser.relationship_to_accused: community member who claimed to have seen him at sabbat

testimony.quarrel_subject: being called a witch by Nicolas Bernard's wife; business rivalry
testimony.threat_quote: luy avoit ja donné des esguillons, et que s'il la pouvoit reprendre qu'il ne s'y espargneroit

testimony.quarrel_subject: great quarrel with him and his wife
testimony.threat_quote: les enffans estoient sy ennuyeux qu'on ne les pouvoit deschasser

testimony.quarrel_subject: accused his son of stealing apples and being a thief

testimony.threat_quote: que s'il luy debvoit couster la vie qu'il auroit des livres d'igromencien et qu'il scauroit ce que c'estoit d'igromancie

testimony.quarrel_subject: husband refused to do work for him
refused to do work because too busy

testimony.threat_quote: que pour la question qu'il ne s'en soucioit tout autant que de rien, et qu'il n'en parle point

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Confronted with Jean Colin, porchier of Raon, who maintained accusation that he had seen him at sabbat

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Interrogation and confrontations with witnesses; denied all charges

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Tortured with thumbscrews, rack, tortillons, and strappado with 50 pound weight for 15 minutes; refused to confess

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Interrogated again after torture; continued to refuse confession

timeline.subject: Gaspard Didier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy orders that he be renvoyé (released/discharged)

prior_accusations.context: Claimed to have seen him at sabbat; this was the formal accusation that initiated the trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: qu'il falloit aller a Strasbourg la ou on y vendit des diables familiaires et qu'ilz luy donneroient de l'argent
notable_quotes.english: that one should go to Strasbourg where familiar devils are sold and they would give him money
notable_quotes.context: Conversation with Jean Piernille about how he managed to enrich himself

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: que non, que quand il avoit de l'argent assez qu'il s'en faut defaire, et que s'il avoit un enffans masle luy mettre entre les mains, et qu'il n'y avoit point de damnation a cela
notable_quotes.english: no, that when one had enough money one should get rid of it [the familiar], and if one had a male child put it in his hands, and that there was no damnation in that
notable_quotes.context: Continuing conversation about familiar spirits, suggesting one could avoid damnation by giving the familiar to a male child

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: les enffans estoient sy ennuyeux qu'on ne les pouvoit deschasser
notable_quotes.english: children were so annoying that one could not chase them away
notable_quotes.context: Said when visiting Mongeotte's dying child, showing lack of sympathy

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: que s'il luy debvoit couster la vie qu'il auroit des livres d'igromencien et qu'il scauroit ce que c'estoit d'igromancie
notable_quotes.english: that if it should cost him his life he would have books of necromancy and would know what necromancy was
notable_quotes.context: Statement to widow of Humbert Claude Marchal about obtaining books of necromancy

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: que pour la question qu'il ne s'en soucioit tout autant que de rien, et qu'il n'en parle point
notable_quotes.english: that as for torture he cared nothing about it, and not to speak of it
notable_quotes.context: Response to ex-mayor's warning about torture if he was not a worthy man

notable_quotes.speaker: Gaspard Didier
notable_quotes.french: qu'il est vray qu'il lisoit dans un livre de planette aultrement appellé calendre et que c'estoit la verité qu'il lisoit ce qui estoit dans ledit livre, mais qu'il n'adjousta beaucoup de foid
notable_quotes.english: that it is true he was reading in a book of planets otherwise called a calendar and that it was the truth he was reading what was in the said book, but that he did not put much faith in it
notable_quotes.context: His explanation about reading fortune from a book to Babillon femme Nicolas Parisot

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Bernard's wife
notable_quotes.french: luy avoit ja donné des esguillons, et que s'il la pouvoit reprendre qu'il ne s'y espargneroit
notable_quotes.english: had already given him spurs/goads, and that if he could catch her again he would not spare himself
notable_quotes.context: Gaspard's threat against Nicolas Bernard's wife for calling him a witch

relationships.evidence_text: his brother told him he was being rumoured a witch
12 years earlier he had been servant of widow of Humbert Claude Marchal
with whom Gaspard had half share
had been drinking to purchase of house by brother in law
Babillon femme Nicolas Parisot was evidently Piernille's sister
omitting 3,000 horse nails when they divided assets
Lucas Guerard had seduced his maid
rival smiths competing for same shoeing work

economic_context.details: Multiple instances of business rivalry among smiths. Gaspard had business partnership disputes with Jean Piernille (division of assets, alleged theft of 3,000 horse nails). Competition with other smiths (Lucas Guerard, Nicolas Arnould at St Blaise) over customers. Discussion about how Gaspard managed to 'enrich himself' while others worked hard for no gain. Given worthless coin (écu for 10 francs) to Jean Henry. Membership dispute in confrérie de St Eloy about not taking business from others. Half-share arrangement with widow of Humbert Claude Marchal.

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Mongeotte femme Gerard Demenge
harms_catalog.harm_description: child burned hand outside his house, developed great contusion on neck, lost use of senses within three days, died after 3 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: great quarrel with him and his wife
harms_catalog.method_alleged: touch (burned hand outside his house, developed contusion on neck)

harms_catalog.harm_description: became strangely ill, talking of 'la mauvaise parolle que j'ay dit' until death
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: told Gaspard he was rumored to be a witch; Gaspard made threat against Nicolas Bernard's wife

harms_catalog.harm_description: became very rebellious with parents as he had never been before
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Gaspard accused son of stealing apples and being great thief

harms_catalog.harm_description: found dead next morning in stable; ball of hair mixed with something like ink found inside when cutting it up
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Gaspard had given a drink to the horse

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill immediately after telling Gaspard of suspicions, said he must die
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: told Gaspard of suspicions about him being a witch

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill suddenly and strangely, remained ill for 5 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicolas shod horses that should have been Gaspard's work; Gaspard spoke disdainfully to him
his valet found Nicolas at work and spoke sharply, saying he would tell his master

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, required spending money on caring for her
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute over worthless coin given as payment

harms_catalog.harm_description: 3 separate accidents: one to leg, other 2 to hand with axe or knife
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to do some work for him because too busy

material_culture.context: Gaspard reading from planetary book/calendar to predict futures
Gaspard threatened to obtain books of necromancy
Gaspard suggested buying familiar devils at Strasbourg
Worthless coin given to Jean Henry for wood cutting
Mongeotte obtained from Gaspard's house to make soup for dying child as counter-magic

material_culture.object: ball of hair mixed with something like ink
material_culture.context: Found inside dead horse of Nicolas Malingre
Allegedly omitted by Jean Piernille when dividing assets with Gaspard
Lucas Guerard's son accused of stealing
Jean Villaume accused of stealing when he fell from tree
Tools with which Idoulx Oudinot injured himself in accidents
George Grand Colas helped harness horse; it went wild and injured child

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
Neighboring village about 4km from Raon where Nicolas Arnould worked as smith
City where Gaspard jokingly suggested one could buy familiar devils
Home of Anthoine Bergier who claimed Gaspard harmed him
Home of Nicolas Malingre, carter whose horse died
Location where Demenge Mathieu was ex-maire
Origin of man drinking with Gaspard when ex-mayor visited
Where Gaspard was reading large book and making predictions
Where Jean Piernille and Gaspard were when discussing rumors

spatial_references.place_name: tavern of Marie femme Jean Marande
spatial_references.context: Where Demenge Pottier and Chrestofle Remy called Gaspard a witch while he was in another room

economic_hardship_indicators: Jean Piernille complained about working hard for no gain while Gaspard enriched himself
Discussion about need for money and familiar devils to provide it

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Piernille allegedly omitted 3,000 horse nails when dividing assets with Gaspard; Gaspard called him liar and thief
Dispute in confrérie de St Eloy about taking business away from other members
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Complex answer suggesting they had reached some agreement

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Marande claimed Gaspard had made reparation to him for something

legal_context.redress_outcome: Gaspard went to see curé to ask him to remonstrate with Jean Colin about the sabbat accusation, but denied giving money

change_de_nancy.modification_details: First approved torture (question ordinaire et extraordinaire) on 30 January 1620, then ordered release (renvoyé) on 4 February 1620 after he refused to confess under torture

hearsay_chains.content: heard her claim that he had caused death of her child
heard him say that if Gaspard was witch he had done him harm
heard him say he had become ill immediately after telling Gaspard of suspicions
heard him claim that accused had given drink to his horse which was found dead

hearsay_chains.source: Demenge Pottier and late Chrestofle Remy
hearsay_chains.content: heard them say Gaspard must be burned and was a witch
heard of suspicions that he had caused death of her son
heard claim that accused had touched Nicolas Bernard's child on neck and caused fatal illness
when witness visited him, he expressed suspicions that Gaspard had bewitched him

emotional_state_notes: declared himself ready to undergo torture
would confess nothing under torture, calling on Jesus Christ to be his aid
at times said he wanted to die, and forgave them for his death
continued to refuse confession even after torture

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Jean Piernille was liar and thief, who had admitted omitting 3,000 horse nails when they divided assets
Babillon femme Nicolas Parisot was evidently Piernille's sister and had been party to fraud when division was made
Jean Villaume was a bastard and son of a whore, and had fallen out of a tree and injured himself badly when stealing pears
Claimed he had told Demenge Maxant's wife in form of a threat 'que le temps iceluy ne durera pas tousjours et qu'apres le temps cy qu'il en viendroit une autre'
Lucas Guerard had seduced his maid under promise of marriage and broken oath as member of confrérie de St Eloy not to take business away from others

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a remarkably detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony. Key features: (1) Gaspard Didier was a blacksmith whose case involved significant business rivalries with other smiths in the region. (2) He was released (renvoyé) by the Change de Nancy after refusing to confess even under extensive torture. (3) The trial originated from Jean Colin's accusation of seeing him at sabbat. (4) Notable for Gaspard's provocative statements about buying familiar devils in Strasbourg and obtaining necromancy books - these could be interpreted as either dark humor or genuine interest in magical knowledge. (5) His economic status is assessed as 'middling' based on evidence that he was enriching himself, had business partnerships, employed servants, and engaged in commercial disputes. (6) The trial shows strong evidence of economic tensions within the blacksmith trade, including disputes over asset division, theft accusations, and guild/confraternity rules about taking business from competitors. (7) Hearsay testimony is extensive, with multiple witnesses reporting what others said rather than firsthand experience. (8) The case against him appears primarily based on reputation (mentioned by 13 witnesses with durations from 3-7 years) and economic/social conflicts rather than direct evidence. (9) His defense strategy was combative - he attacked witnesses' credibility and accused them of crimes rather than offering natural explanations for alleged harms. (10) The torture session was severe (thumbscrews, rack, tortillons, strappado with 50 lb weight for 15 minutes) but he steadfastly refused to confess. (11) Several witnesses are spouses of other witnesses, creating family networks in the testimony. (12) Geographic spread includes St Blaise (4km away), suggesting regional rather than purely local accusations. (13) The 'renvoyé' outcome is significant - the Change de Nancy first approved torture, then after he endured it without confession, ordered his release. This suggests the appellate court found insufficient evidence for conviction.
